title: Fitch Affirms Land Bank of the Philippines at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable
text:
Fitch Affirms Land Bank of the Philippines at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable

(The following statement was released by the rating agency) Fitch Ratings-Singapore-October 30: Fitch Ratings has affirmed the Long-Term Foreign- and Local-Currency Issuer Default Ratings (IDR) of state-owned Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP) at 'BBB'. The Outlook is Stable. Key Rating Drivers IDRS, SUPPORT RATING AND SUPPORT RATING FLOOR LBP's IDRs are equalised with those of the sovereign, reflecting our expectations of a high probability of extraordinary state support for the bank in times of need. This drives the bank's Support Rating of '2' and Support Rating Floor of 'BBB'. The ratings take into account the bank's policy role, 100% state ownership and high systemic importance, which is indicated by its market share of about 11%-13% of system assets and deposits and status as the largest recipient of government deposits. The ratings also consider the state's ability to provide support, reflected in the 'BBB' sovereign rating. The bank is mandated to promote rural development in the Philippines, and also plays a role in various government financial programmes as needed. The board is appointed by the Philippine president annually, with four cabinet secretaries as ex officio members including the Philippine secretary of finance as chairperson. VIABILITY RATING LBP's Viability Rating considers the impact of state ownership and control on the bank's risk appetite, as well as the risks associated with its high concentration of large borrowers and niche policy-oriented portfolio, which may render it more vulnerable to impairment shocks. This is balanced against its satisfactory standalone credit profile, reflecting its generally stable funding and liquidity profile, moderate operating performance and adequate capital buffers. These stem from the state's requirement that LBP remains financially viable even as it fulfills its policy mandate. Around 92% of gross loans were extended to policy priority sectors as of end-2018. Loans are, for the most part, extended on a commercial basis, which has allowed the bank to maintain satisfactory profitability over the years despite its heavy policy focus. Average operating profit/risk-weighted assets of around 2.4% over 2015-2018 compares well against privately owned peers, notwithstanding the bank's more limited revenue diversification and more concentrated loan portfolio, which could lead to greater earnings volatility. LBP's Fitch Core Capital ratio of 14.6% and regulatory common equity Tier 1 ratio of 11.9% at end-2018 formed an adequate buffer for the bank to expand and guard against impairment shocks. LBP has been granted dividend exemptions, ordinary capital infusions and regulatory relief by the state in recent years, which have helped it retain capital for further growth. LBP's funding and liquidity profile is generally healthy. Deposits accounted for the bulk (about 98%) of funding, and a majority were government deposits thanks to its state ownership. The balance sheet is liquid, reflected in the low loan/deposit ratio of 47% at end-2018 and liquidity coverage ratio of 210% at end-June 2019. RATING SENSITIVITIES IDRS, SUPPORT RATING AND SUPPORT RATING FLOOR The ratings would be sensitive to any perceived shift in the sovereign's ability or propensity to support the bank. This may occur with sovereign rating action. Negative action could also arise if the state were to significantly reduce its ownership in LBP, or if the bank's policy role were to be curtailed - which we do not expect in the near-to-medium term. VIABILITY RATING There is little scope for a Viability Rating upgrade unless LBP's policy role and government involvement were to shrink significantly. Significant asset quality deterioration or unrestrained credit growth that materially weakens its buffers would be negative for its standalone credit profile, though this risk is mitigated by the bank's acceptable risk standards and the requirement for LBP to remain self-sustaining financially. ESG Considerations Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of 3 - ESG issues are credit neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. LBP has an ESG Relevance Score of 4 for Governance Structure. This reflects our view of a moderate risk of government influence that negatively affects its standalone credit profile, in light of its full state ownership and state-appointed board. For more information on our ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg.
